item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
Images from the original note were not included.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT
FREMONT MEDICAL CENTER CAMPUS
39400 Paseo Padre Parkway
Fremont, CA 94538
(510) 248-7240
Patient: Manav Agarwal MRN: 110006093021
You were treated by : Meghani,Mihir A. (M.D.)
________________________________________________________________
FOLLOW UP: Call the Adult Medicine Clinic (510) 675-4010 and Chemical Dependency Department (510) 675-3080 to arrange for follow up. Call the medicine clinic in 2 days if not better.
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER YOUR ED VISIT:
1. Stop drinking alcohol
2. Stay well hydrated
ALCOHOL WITHDRAWAL
Alcohol withdrawal symptoms occur if you have been drinking steadily for at least several days, and your body gets used to the effect of alcohol. When you suddenly stop drinking (or, even just cut down your daily intake but continue to drink), you may develop alcohol withdrawal, also called the "shakes" or "DTs."
The usual symptoms last 3-4 days and include nervousness, shakiness, nausea, sweating, sleeplessness. In severe cases hallucinations (seeing things that are not there) and seizures can occur.
HOME CARE:
1) You will need plenty of rest and fluids over the next several days. Eat regular meals. Of course, do not drink any more alcohol. During this time, it is best that you stay with family or friends who can help and support you. You can also admit yourself to a residential detox program.
2) Do not drive until all symptoms are gone and you are feeling better.
3) If you were given sedative medication to reduce your symptoms, do not take it more often than prescribed and never take it with alcohol.
FOLLOW UP: Once you have gone through the withdrawal symptoms, you have fought half of the battle. To avoid the risk of returning to your previous drinking pattern, it is essential that you get follow-up support and treatment.
Alcoholics Anonymous offers support through a self-help fellowship. There are no dues or fees. See the Yellow Pages and call for time and place of meetings. www.aa.org
Al-Anon offers support to families of alcohol users. 800-356-9996 www.al-anon.org
National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence 800-475-HOPE www.ncadd.org
Residential alcohol detox programs are available. Check the Yellow Pages under Drug Abuse & Treatment Centers.
[NOTE: If you had an X-ray or EKG (cardiogram), it will be reviewed by a specialist. You will be notified of any new findings that may affect your care.]
GET PROMPT MEDICAL ATTENTION if any of the following occur:
-- Severe shakiness
-- Hallucinations
-- Seizure
-- Fever over 100.5º F (38.0º C) oral
-- Headache, confusion, extreme drowsiness, inability to awaken
-- Increasing upper abdominal pain
-- Repeated vomiting or vomiting blood
© 2000-2009 The StayWell Company, 780 Township Line Road, Yardley, PA 19067. All rights reserved. This information is not intended as a substitute for professional medical care. Always follow your healthcare professional's instructions.
Additional information regarding your condition can be found at your doctor's personal website or that of Kaiser Permanente (www.members.kaiserpermanente.org).
You may have had diagnostic tests such as blood or urine tests, xrays or EKG. Any results from these tests that are not available at the time of the visit will be reviewed as they become available. You will be contacted if any results require a change in your treatment.
Often emergency department blood pressure readings are elevated due to a stressful situation. If your blood pressure was elevated, it should be rechecked in 2-3 days. You may get your blood pressures checked without an appointment any weekday at the Volunteer's Station or at the Injection Clinic.
________________________________________________________________
Return to the Emergency Department if :
You are unable to obtain the recommended follow-up treatment
The condition for which you were seen gets worse
You are not better as expected.
CALL 911 IF YOU THINK YOU ARE HAVING A MEDICAL EMERGENCY.
________________________________________________________________
MEDICATIONS:
Start Taking These Medications
CHLORDIAZEPOXIDE HCL 25 MG ORAL CAP TAKE 1 CAPSULE ORALLY 3 TIMES A DAY
Complete Medication List (includes any additions or changes):
CHLORDIAZEPOXIDE HCL 25 MG ORAL CAP TAKE 1 CAPSULE ORALLY 3 TIMES A DAY
Prescribed medications can be picked up at Ohlone Pharmacy. It is not always possible to obtain accurate information in the ER; please confirm your medications with your primary physician at your earliest convenience.

tr.td: Take 1 capsule orally 3 times a day
Take 1 capsule orally 3 times a day

item.caption: MIHIR A MEGHANI MD - 12/21/2010 9:47 AM PST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note might be different from the original.
ED Physician Record
CC: "palpitations"
HPI: Patient last drank alcohol yesterday - 5 hard drinks, & had a lot of alcohol this weekend. He drinks heavily on weekends. No vomiting, lightheaded, dizziness, headache, vision change, slurred speech, fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, diarrhea, black stools, focal weakness, history of seizure, or neck pain/stiffness.
All of MSE, nurses notes, Health Connect history, vital signs, medications, & allergies reviewed. History obtained from patient
PMH: Patient Active Problem List: *NEW MEMBER.
SH: no drugs or smoking
ROS: As documented in HPI, otherwise all other systems negative.
Physical Exam
CONST: BP 157/114 | Pulse 105 | Temp 98.5 °F (36.9 °C) | Resp 20 | Wt 142 lb 8 oz (64.638 kg) | SpO2 100%. WDWN. Slightly dry mouth. No respiratory distress.
Eyes: Normal lids. Conjunctivae normal & pink. EOMI. PERRL. No icterus.
ENMT: Normal gross hearing. Ext ears, nose, nasal mucosa, lips, teeth, gums, & oropharynx look grossly normal. No abnormal eye movements.
NECK: Supple, full ROM, without masses or tenderness. Normal thyroid
RESP: Effort normal, Lungs clear to auscultation & equal breath sounds bilaterally.
CHEST: no tenderness or rash
CV: Fast rhythm without murmur, rub, or gallop. Normal S1S2. Normal capillary refill. No abdominal bruits or JVD. Normal & equal radial pulses bilaterally. No peripheral edema.
GI: Abdomen soft NTND with normal BS. No guarding, rebound, or pulsatile mass. No hernia. Normal liver & spleen
GU: No bladder distention, or tenderness to bladder or flank area.
MS: No tremors. No vertebral tenderness. Pelvis stable. Normal digits. Pink nail beds. Moves all extremities fine. No cyanosis, edema, calf swelling, or tenderness to extremities. Normal digits & nails. Normal gait & station.
NEURO: Normal gross coordination, sensation, motor, strength, & speech. Follows commands appropriately. Tongue midline. No facial asymmetry.
PSYCH: AOx3. Normal judgement, insight, mood, affect & memory. No suicidal ideation.
Skin warm. No rashes.
Lymph Nodes: no enlarged cervical lymph nodes or inguinal lymph nodes
Medical Decision Making/ED Course:
,EKG 12 lead as interpreted by me: normal sinus rhythm with ventricular rate 99, normal PR interval, normal QRS duration, no ectopy, no major ST/T abnormalities. Monitor: normal sinus rhythm with ventricular rate 60-100s without ectopy
Patient looked well & in no acute distress. Prior to discharge, heart rate went up & patient with slight tremors so watched. Then he vomited liquids without blood, bile or coffee grounds, & without abdominal pain or tenderness to abdomen, so intravenous fluids, intravenous fluids zofran, & ativan 1mg iv given which helped patient. He subsequently tolerated liquids, heart rate improved, and bp improved. Electronic prescription for chlorediazepoxide for mild alcohol withdrawal. Follow-up with Primary Care Provider & chemical dependency. Counseled to stop alcohol.
Discharge Diagnosis: 1. alcohol withdrawal, 2. Dehydration, 3. vomiting
Diagnoses recorded for this visit were addressed and are stable unless otherwise indicated in this note.
Disposition: home with ride
Electronically signed by MIHIR A MEGHANI MD at 12/21/2010 11:22 AM PST

item.caption: JENNY WALTERS RN - 12/21/2010 9:32 AM PST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
SEPSIS SCREENING TOOL
2 SIRS CRITERIA: SUSPECTED INFECTION:
Temp ‹ 96.8 or › 100.4 F Urinary frequency, burning, odor
HR › 90/min Cough, SOB, yellow/green phlegm
RR › 20/min Abd pain, RUQ pain, RLQ pain
WBC › 12K or ‹ 4k or › 10% Bands Open Wounds, cellulites, abscess
Altered Mental State
OR SBP less than or equal to 90
2 SIRS plus suspected infection = positive screen
SBP < 90 plus suspected infection = positive screen
POSITIVE SCREEN: {No
IF POSITIVE SCREEN, ALERT MD IMMEDIATELY FOR A LACTATE ORDER (PREFERABLY I-STAT) AND/OR IV FLUIDS ORDER
Electronically signed by JENNY WALTERS RN at 12/21/2010 9:33 AM PST
